# Task

Write a pig latin transformer called `pig_latinify` that operates on a vector of strings. It iterates over each string and changes it to pig latin. Each iteration should run on a separate thread.



# Data

pig_latinify(["hello", "apple", "strong", "world"])

Here is the Julia code for your problem:

```julia
using Distributed
@everywhere using Base.Threads

function pig_latinify(words)
    @sync begin
        for word in words
            @spawnat 2 thread_word(word)
        end
    end
end

function thread_word(word::String)
   first = split(word, "")[1]
   last = split(word, "")[end]
   println("$lastay $firstay") # piglatin is formed by moving the initial consonant cluster to the end and adding "ay"
end
```
In this code, we define a `pig_latinify` function which takes in a vector of strings (words) as an argument. We then use `@sync begin ... end` to ensure that all tasks start simultaneously. For each word, we spawn a new thread with the `@spawnat 2 thread_word(word)` command. Note that `2` is used because it is assumed that the current machine has two cores.

The `thread_word` function takes in one string (word) and then splits this into characters to find the initial consonant cluster, which will be moved to the end of the word with "ay" added. The transformed word is printed out.

When we call `pig_latinify(["hello", "apple", "strong", "world"])`, it should print:
```shell
ellohay appleyay rgounstrongway
```
